												I was starting to get into it. A nice, casual free to play MMORPG with turn-based combat. Detailed story. Plenty of things to do. I hit level 10 and got access to my Haven Bag, which is like a telelporter to your personal space. They gave me a chest to store my items, so I immediately tried to offload my starter equipment. Dragged my old boots from inventory to chest. "This content is restricted to subscribers." They follow this with a list explaining that only subscribers can have pets, play PVP, get special quests, visit all of the lands, ETC...At level 10, this free to play becomes a DEMO.

number of helpful: 49 of 66 people (74%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 15, 2016
												DISCLAIMER: I've re-written this several times, unhappy with each. I have decided to stop doing that and just write how I feel instead of sounding professional. As someone who found Dofus when it was first in beta, I feel almost ashamed to admit I've been playing this game as long as I have. In fact, It might be for the best that it's only now reaching steam, as I fear seeing the hours I've poured into this game might be traumatizing. Heck, the hours I might pour into this game AFTER this point intimidate me..... but alas, there's a reason I have stuck around as long as I have. THIS. GAME. IS. AMAZING. Why? because I said so! Okay, I'll be a bit more specific.... Appearance - I start here, because I frankly see little reason to go over it. You see the top of the page, you saw the trailer (granted it's a mishmash of the movie and the game, well done, nonetheless). And it's the thing that will catch people's attention. I, for one, LOVE the artstyle and direction Ankama has chosen to go, but something I should mention. It looks cartooney, and childish, don't let that throw you off, this game is VERY much aimed at young adults and adults. It might be a bit too complex for young children, and the dialogue and....ahem...references... assume a respectable level of maturity. That is to say, there is adult humor all over the place (think condom sword, and rabbits vandalizing fox(tanouki) statues by placing a giant wooden log between their legs...) so don't be afraid. Also note this game isn't just a ton of sex humor, Ankama is pretty classy, after all. Gameplay - The main reason you'll get sucked in...or turned off. Dofus is a turn based strategy MMORPG, which I can understand some people not enjoying, I do. The game is very skill intensive, almost no reflexes needed. There are currently 17 classes to chose from, and I can tell you, don't bother asking what the "best" anything is. There is no "best" character, "best" build, "best" equipment or the likes. Ankama has done a marvelous job at keeping the classes ballanced. Speaking of the classes, the 17 classes all play VERY differently, leading many people to play multiple (oh yeah, multiclienting is a thing, and is supported in this game. That is both good and bad, depending who you ask). If you're just starting out, don't worry about playing multiple characters, it's not necessary to succeed, just keep in mind someone using 6 accounts will progress faster than someone using 1 or 2. Uniqueness - The only thing even remotely comparable to Dofus is Wakfu, which is almost a sequel to Dofus, and is the same company. There's nothing even remotely comparable in the MMORPG market. If you've ever played Final Fantasy Tactics, or a similar game, you should catch on pretty quickly. Accessability - The game is flash based, making it so it's not particularly taxing on even weak computers. After major updates, the game can be a little less comparable (such as the recent interface changes) but even with a mid-range laptop with integrated graphics, I had little issue playing several accounts at once. I also run on a poor net connection (I'm talking average ~200-250 ping, with spikes regularly) and it causes little trouble for me. There is a respectable free-to-play area that anyone can try out to find out if they like it before paying a penny. The game is also multi platform, working on mac and I believe still linux. The learning curve can be steep, and the initial game overwhelming, but that can't be helped with something as unique as this. Management - Ankama as a company is one of the companies I respect the most. They have been phenominal at maintaining ballance between the classes, They are good at storytelling (granted they could use some work in the presentation in game...) and their use of the cash shop (Also known as the Ogrine Market, their cash currency) has been great. The items you can buy on the cash shop are almost entirely cosmetic, with a couple minor convienances. Also you can buy the currency with in-game money, as is the case with many games, and it's pretty reasonable to do so, and you can also use the method to subscribe characters. Customer support is famously aweful, by american standards, but when you look at it with the realization that the company is french, where customer support is a totally different perception, it's actually not bad. Izmar (the community manager) is also incredibly helpful and friendly, and very good at making sure things are running smoothly (she deserves a big raise!)Longevity - I've been playing it for well over a decade..... I think that's enough said. I admit I am not a crazy hardcore player, but there's still plenty I haven't done and still want to do. Customization - Character customization is a weak point here. Hats and cloaks are the only displayed equipment, you can chose colors of your character by picking 5 predetermined areas and coloring those to your liking, and you can chose between m/f and 8 different faces. Otherwise there's not a ton of options. The interface has recently gone through an overhaul and you are now able to move interfaces around to your liking, but even that could use a little more freedom. Social - The guild system is O.K., the alliance system is interesting, and multiclienting people can play on their own no problem. With that said, You will meet some interesting people in this game, there are plenty of chat channels you can access, and the community is generally pretty friendly. In PvP obviously there is drama and hostility, but it's nothing comparable to what you'd find in arena games. Bang for your buck - The game is relatively cheap for a subscription game, and the cash shop is nothing near necessary to keep up (in fact, you CANT realistically keep up with other people just by dumping cash into the game), and you can subscribe with in-game currency at a rate that is normally relatively decent. I would advise avoiding trying to use in-game currency for your first month or 3, but after that is when alot of people are able to transfer over, not that supporting ankama is bad by any stretch, and paying with real money makes the game less stressful, as you don't have to worry about upkeeping subscription. Footnotes - Note that this game is oldschool. Level 200 (max) isn't when the game starts (or ends, for that matter), so you don't need to rush to high level. There is a huge amount of content. The official forums and subreddit are also great resources for newcomers, and those may help you avoid being overwhelmed. If you're into solo play, awesome, but keep in mind this game is designed for team content, and high level content will require you to team up at least some, or a ton if you find yourself questing. I look forward to all the new faces! ~Pirotek of Rosemary on Rushu

number of helpful: 14 of 20 people (70%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 15, 2016
												Note: if you’re picking this up with friends, just make sure you’re put on the same server, so you can explore it together. When you first start, you’re going to be randomly sorted into one of the available INTernational servers by default. You can click the small “Manual server selection” to make sure you go on Rosal server together, for example.Don’t be fooled by the cute artwork! Dofus is not a typical mmo, and has a lot of depth. The game was released more than a decade ago, and has kept evolving and growing since then. If you’re at all a fan or interested in tactical gameplay, you will like the combat. I’ve always compared it to FFTA (final fantasy tactics advance), but far more dynamic, and set in a large MMO world. It’s the many interesting classes and their mechanics that have kept me playing all this time.This unique world has a wealth of stories, secrets, quests and achievements. You’ll also play the game through your friends, as this is an MMO after all, and play against them too: there are opportunities to fight against others not just nearby, but internationally and across all servers as well.In the end, Dofus is a game set in a fantastic universe, that lets you choose what sort of experience you’d like, with no shortage of content. I’ve personally tried many other MMOs, and nothing (except for Wakfu somewhat, and it’s the same developer) comparesIt’s free to download and try, and subscribing (not a recurring thing, you get 1 week/month/3months/6months/year at a time) allows you to interact with things outside of the first few areas. Believe me though, it’s definitely worth it. There’s also a system that will essentially allow you to play for free, and use the in-game currency to buy subscription time.http://www.dofus.com/en/play/silverhandii

												I remember being apart of the beta launch and couldn't continue my character afterwards due to all of the subscirption restrictions. content:
Posted: December 12, 2016
												I have poured hundreds and hundres of hours into this game. I really liked it, but got a little burned out and left for a while. When I came back, I found my server to be almost completely dead. There is no one here who does anything with other people, its all a bunch of people running 6+ characters at once and soloing all the content. Which is not a terrible thing.  This is really the only mmo where you can realistically play solo, which I really like. However, as a new player just starting out it makes it very difficult. No one is available to help you, you just have to figure it out on your own. I would still recommend the game, just be sure to check out which server to start on. Some are much more active than others.Also, as mentioned before multiclienting is allowed and even encouraged, and in my opinion is the best way to play the game as it can take quite a long time waiting for your turn with only one character, but I have not been able to figure out how to do it off the Steam client, which is a deal breaker for me since I have 5 characters.

number of helpful: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 18, 2016
												If you've ever played a turn based game in your life and even somewhat enjoyed it, you really need to play DOFUS. I've been playing on and off for 10 years. Occasionally I'll take a break because of life/boredom and I'll go try out another game. Yet DOFUS always pulls me back in due to how frequently its updated and how unique it really is. How many mmorpgs do you know that offer an enriching turnbased combat? I have yet to encounter a single one outside DOFUS/WAKFU. Not only that but the class system is great. 17 soon to be 18 classes that are both distinct from each other and so unique from many mmorpgs. How many games do you know where there exists a class solely devoted to getting drunk and throwing people across the map? I acknowledge that without subbing you can only get up to levels 40-60 or so without really pulling your teeth out, but the subscription cost is very cheap as far as sub-based games go and definitely worth it. Final comment on the matter is the pvp system. 1v1 pvp is very enjoyable but the rewards are mostly cosmetics. However the 3v3 pvp system that unlocks when you hit level 50 is amazing. I'm someone that usually avoids pvp, but turnbased pvp with friends (or even randoms) in a small team like that just somehow works so well. Not to mention you get tons of money and various rewards for winning.  I don't have much else to say besides please give this great game a try. If you ever need help starting out just message me and I'd be glad to show you around and get you started.

number of helpful: 5 of 10 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 16, 2016
												Hello, and welcome to Dofus!Dofus is a turn based strategy MMORPG. It started out with 12 classes (hence the name "World of Twelve"), but in the past couple of years they've added more and more classes which have spiced up the game a lot! This is one of the best games I've ever played, and I'm not just saying that. I've been playing this game for over a decade and I've loved every minute of it.    This game will challenge you in almost every way a game can. There are 17 classes (with hints of an 18th), and each class has 22 spells that are unique to that class. There are even more spells that all classes can have, but you must overcome different challenges to obtain them. Dofus takes a little getting used to when you first start playing, but as soon as you start getting on a roll the fun is endless! There are over 16,000 achievements that you can unlock ranging from extremely easy to damn near impossible! Unlocking an achievement will give you a certain amount of gold and experience depending on how difficult it was to unlock it.This is a game for both the hardcore gamers and the casual gamers! It just depends on your playstyle.There is an awesome system for Guilds, and Alliances in place that allows the players to control the map. If your Alliance is in control of the area you get a boost in EXP and drops! Other Alliances can attack areas they don't own to try take them over and you have to defend in a timed King Of The Hill that can result in a warzone of PvP fights!The players own the economy, so depending on which server you play on, the item that you want to buy may or may not be in the market. Unless you want to make the item yourself you can level up to 18 different professions by creating items using all the materials in their respected recipes (harder to make items give you more EXP, but require more mats).There is an enormous variety of monsters of different skill levels that each drop their own unique materials that you can sell, use, or make into certain items! You won't find yourself sitting around looking for things to do! There's so much more, but I would be typing for days, and even I don't know everything about the game!USEFULL EXTERNAL SITES:https://www.dofusplanner.com/  Use this site to find certain item combinations that will make your character even stronger!http://dofuswiki.wikia.com/wiki/Dofus_Wiki  This is the Dofus Wiki page; it will help you a lot with your journey if you ever get stuck, or want to know what a certain monster does, and how to beat it. Keep in mind though that it is player made, and so it might not have everything about the game in it.I HIGHLY recommend you play this game, I know you won't regret it! You can go to http://www.dofus.com/en/play/trilkgh to register your account and start playing today! Hope to see you in game! (Izmar, Please tell me if it's against the rules to advertise my Friend Referral link. Thank you!)

												Definitely recommend.I've been playing for years, and although there have been some changes I disliked, the game is constantly being updated with new, better content to keep it exciting and fresh. The community is fantastic.Although it is advertised as free to play, the game DOES run on a monthly subscription model. You do not have to sub to play, and you can get a feel for things in the two starting areas. The game is NOT pay to win, either. You pay to play, but you don't have to buy gear or buffs or stats from the company to be on an equal footing with everyone else.I highly recommend giving it a try.

content:
Posted: November 24, 2016
												I originally started playing this game almost ten years ago, before Dofus 2.0 (current iteration) released and when it was a very different game (such as alignment wars between Bonta and Brakmar were far more involved than they are ever since Kolossium.  Nonetheless, if you have the patience for grinding (quests are almost all fairly worthless compared to just leveling off specific PvE mobs) and prefer a more tactical style of combat with turned based actions, Doufs is worth a shot at playing.Granted, Ankama has made a large number of mistakes over the years with development decisions and had a nasty habit of completing ignoring large portions of the community in favor of specific niches, but the game itself has still managed to survive a company that did its popularity no favors.  Hopefully trying to start a revivial by making it available on Steam will help, because this is definitely not a game you should try to play alone.

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 15, 2016
												Dofus is not your typical MMO. It is designed, from the ground up, to be a fun, engaging, and visually stunning game... in 2D. Aesthetically, there are few games that can compare to the cohesive, stylistic beauty that marks Dofus, which transports us to a world where fantasy and magic feel real and new, much like my generation saw the bright, vast world of WoW at a young age and fell in love.Dofus, however, is not a mass-appeal game. I can only compare its team to Eve Online in this respect: It knows its audience, and it does a damn good job of pumping out the kind of content that they love. There are many aspects of Dofus that are unorthodox in today's game market - Non-binding items, a robust economy where professions actually do matter (as they produce all the items in the game), and a class of professions where it is actually possible to change the stats of items and add stats that were not there previously.It isn't all about professions, though. The turn based combat is carried by a gorgeous and well executed litany of spells, abilities, and animations that absoulutely showcase the dedication of the art team. This combat is made interesting not only by the mechanics, but your choice of character build. Character build in this game is, absolutely, your choice. Dofus features the old-style characteristics system where you allocate the points, rather then having them automatically assigned. There are still, of course, cookie cutter builds that some follow, but you do not have to be follow of them to excel: if anything, a person who learns the ins and outs of Dofus has innumerable opportunities to try out novel and interesting character designs that may surprise their fellow players.On the topic of fellow players we reach one of the games many strengths. There are alliances that do nothing but PVE, if thats what you enjoy. There are alliances that do nothing but PVP as well, and of course a smattering that do all sorts of activities together. If alliances are too big a community for you (although alliances themselves vary greatly in size), you can choose  to be in an allianceless guild that is a bit more cozy. (Or you can play solo, talk to nobody, quit, and wonder why you can't enjoy MMOs.)This game has been around for over ten years and I am still amazed by how many helpful, sociable veteran players there are. Although there are complaints about technicalities, as with all game communities, the Dofus community as a whole is passionate about the game they play, and more than willing to guide newcomers on their path to glory, loot, and lasting friendships.I cannot recommend this game enough: Try it, and if you like it, welcome home.

number of helpful: 14 of 38 people (37%) found this review helpful5 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 26, 2016
												I have played Dofus since about 2004. I stopped playing yesterday, Christmas of 2016, because a forum moderator banned me from the Ankama forum on Christmas when I explained in my own words what Christmas was about in a reply to a "Happy Holidays" forum thread started by another forum moderator. The moderator who banned me wrote a nasty letter to me blatantly insulting and persecuting me and Christianity. I told Ankama that as a result of this mistreatment of me, a loyal paying customer of about a decade -- and I have spent many thousands of dollars and so much time playing and contributing to the community -- Ankama denying or otherwise supporting this religious persecution of myself and other Christians, they have lost a customer. Let me be clear that Ankama supports International Human Rights violations and misdemeanors and felonies -- and when you are their victim, you have no recourse except to stop playing their game. Ankama does not issue refunds, nor have they shown any concern for the thoughts of players; they say one thing and then turn around and do the opposite; they lie to your face. Their business is run as a fascist regime, and players must fall into line or be made to suffer. My recourse is that they have lost my business.Dofus was fun for about 10 years, but the very low population in players among the English communities, the complete arrogant elitism of their French company (they are so extremely arrogant in their nationalism, I cannot even explain to you except through citing the stereotypical Frenchman, you would not even believe me if I told you how bloated this French elitism they exhibit is -- for example, they make excuses to IP block everyone from other countries), the lack of respect towards players by their customer service and community managers, and their history of initiating changes that completely ruin the fun of gameplay styles makes this game and any association with this company a disappointing experience for thousands of French and non-French players like myself over the history of the game. Their stifling of free speech is disheartening, and the nasty attitudes of moderators and community managers is seriously off-putting. The community manager Izmar is usually friendly, but experiences with the rest have almost always been upsetting and disappointing for me and those players who have shared their experiences with me.I honestly highly advise the Steam community to stay away from Ankama and Dofus. This is a gaming experience that will cause you harm and no good at all. And if you give them money, you become an even worse-off target in their crosshairs. Do yourself a favor and invest neither time nor money in this game or its company. They are going down the drain, so obviously headed toward bankruptcy and ruin, so don't let yourself get flushed down the toilet with them. You will not have any fun installing and playing Dofus. And God help you if you use their web sites at all. They are a basket of vipers and you will get a snake bite if you let them see you.

content:
Posted: December 1, 2016
												I've been playing this game on and off since 2006.  I love this game and it holds a very special place in my heart. Unfortunately, the game isn't what it once was. What was once an amazing social experience has turned into everyone playing multiple accounts and rarely grouping up with other people to level/do dungeons. The english speaking community is very small compared to what it once was and most people that play, like me, have been playing for many years.I will never forget this game and the love it has instilled in me for turn-based combat. Give it a shot and I hope it brings half the amount of joy it has for me to you.
